The word melach (salt) is related to the word melechah (salt)43In that both words have the meaning of cut. in A fruitful land turned into salt (Ps. 107:34). A salted place is said to be cut off, for nothing grows there. Compare, brimstone, and salt44The verse reads: brimstone, and salt, and a burning, that it is not sown, nor beareth, nor any grass groweth. (Deut. 29:22).
IN RETURN. The word chelef means in return.
AND HENCEFORTH…SHALL NOT COME NIGH. This45The word henceforth. was written because of Korah’s assembly.

BUT THE LEVITES ALONE SHALL DO THE SERVICE.46Our clause literally reads, But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting. Hence the interpretations which follow. The word hu means himself. Others say that hu is the object.47This interpretation renders hu as it. It maintains that But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting should be interpreted: But the Levites shall do the service of it (hu), namely, the tent of meeting (Weiser). Filwarg claims that hu refers to the kohen. In this case, But the Levites he (hu) shall do the service of the tent of meeting should be interpreted: But the Levites shall do the service of him (the kohen) and of the tent of meeting. However, this is incorrect, for the service of the tent of meeting is the object.48Of ve-avad (shall do the service).
AND THEY SHALL BEAR THEIR INIQUITY. If they do not keep the charge. Now, the tithe is their inheritance. I therefore stated: [and among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance].

AND THE LORD SPOKE UNTO MOSES, SAYING. To Moses, not to Aaron, for Scripture goes on to say that the Levites are to give a tithe to Aaron from the tithe [they received].49It would be out of place for Aaron to issue such a command.
AND AS THE FULNESS. I have already explained the meaning of the word mele’ah (fullness).50See I.E. on Ex. 22:25, where he explains mele’ah as referring to wine.

OF ALL THE BEST THEREOF.51Literally, of all the fat thereof (chelbo). Hence I.E.’s explanation. The meaning of mi-kol chelbo is, of all the best thereof. And ye shall eat the fat (chelev) of the land (Gen. 45:18) is similar.52Its meaning is, And you shall eat of the best of the land.
EVEN THE HALLOWED PART THEREOF. For the tenth part thereof is the holy part.53Thus the hallowed part thereof refers to its tithe.

[WHEN YE SET APART THE BEST THEREOF.] This has already been mentioned by Scripture.54In the previous verse. It is repeated in order to connect it to that which follows. Its meaning is, you55The Levites. are prohibited to eat of it56From the tithe given to you. until you set apart the best thereof,57A tenth thereof. and afterwards it58The remainder. shall be counted [as the grain of the threshing floor] and you59The Levites. may eat it in every clean place.60I.E. interprets every place as in every clean place. However, according to the halakha the Levite may eat the remaining tithe even in a cemetery. See Rashi.

AND YE SHALL BEAR NO SIN BY REASON OF IT. This means when you set apart the best of it61A tenth of the tithe. you shall bear no sin through it.62By not tithing (Rashi). Furthermore, when you give the hallowed part thereof,63To the kohen. the sacred donations of the children of Israel will be preserved.64The tithes which the children of Israel gave to the Levites will not be desecrated. However, if you do not offer to tithe, then you will bear a sin, for you will have trespassed the commandment and profaned the holy things of the children of Israel because you ate its holy part.

THIS IS THE STATUTE. This chapter was also1Like the incident of Korah. See I.E. on Num 16:1. stated at Sinai. It was given when God commanded that they put out of the camp…whosoever is unclean by the dead (Num. 5:2). There were also people who were unclean by coming into contact with a dead body when Passover2Celebrated by Israel in the second year after the Exodus. arrived (Num. 9:6). This chapter is placed here3Following the laws dealing with the tithes. because it relates to the kohen.4The kohen played a major role in the ritual of the red heifer.

A RED HEIFER, FAULTLESS. The heifer is not to be small.5For the Bible speaks of a parah (cow), not of an eglah (heifer). The Gaon6Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. says that the water of sprinkling (v. 13)7Which cleansed the unclean but made the clean unclean. is similar to honey, which is injurious to the one who has red bile8In medieval medicine red bile was believed to cause a volatile nature. See I.E. on Ex. 23:25 (Vol. 2, p. 516). but stimulates the one who has phlegm.9An excess of phlegm. This causes a phlegmatic nature. However, there is no need for this interpretation.

AND SHE SHALL BE BROUGHT FORTH. Someone shall bring her forth.10The literal meaning of ve-hotzi otah is: and he shall bring her forth. However, since Eleazar did not actually slaughter the cow, I.E. believes that he did not bring it out. Hence his comment. Or it means he shall have her brought forth by his command.11In other words, it means he shall command that it be brought out. The same applies to ve-shachat (and she shall be slain),12Which literally means: and he shall slaughter it. for Eleazar did not slaughter the heifer. The word le-fanav (before his face) proves the latter.13If Eleazar did the slaughtering, then what point would there be for Scripture to say “and he [Eleazar] shall slaughter it before his [Eleazar’s] face.”

AND THE HEIFER SHALL BE BURNT IN HIS SIGHT. Ve-saraf et ha-parah (and the heifer shall be burnt)14The literal meaning of ve-saraf et ha-parah is: and he shall burn the cow. is to be rendered, and someone shall burn the heifer. The term le’enav (in his sight)15Eleazar’s sight. proves the latter interpretation.

CEDAR-WOOD. As in the case of a leper.16Cedar wood was used in cleansing a leper (Lev. 14:4). I have hinted there at some secret.17I.E. points out that there is a connection between leprosy and death. Hence cedar is employed in cleansing someone who has been contaminated by contract with a leper or a dead body.

THEN THE PRIEST SHALL WASH HIS CLOTHES. The kohen who burns it.18Prima facie, the reference is to the cow. However, in view of the fact that the latter is stated in the next verse, some say that the reference is to the cedar. See Filwarg and Krinsky.

AND THE PRIEST SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The meaning of ve-tame ha-kohen (and the priest shall be unclean) is, and the kohen has already been unclean,19The kohen has been made unclean by performing the ritual. According to this interpretation the vav prefixed to ve-tame means “and.” Hence the meaning of ve-tame ha-kohen is: and the kohen was unclean. or, as some say, the kohen shall be unclean.20In this case ve-tame is a future form meaning: and he shall be unclean. The vav is a conversive vav. Until the even refers to the eating of sacred food.

A MAN THAT IS CLEAN. The reference is not to the kohen who burns the cow.21Another kohen does this (Krinsky). According to the Sifre on this verse, any clean person, even if not a kohen, may gather the ashes of the red cow. However, I.E. seems to believe that this task was assigned to a kohen.

A WATER OF SPRINKLING. The meaning of niddah (sprinkling) is distance.22The person who is unclean is distanced from the sanctuary. Thus me-niddah (water of sprinkling) means the water of the distant, i.e., the water to be used to purify the distant. Compare, me-naddekhem23Me-naddekhem comes from the same root as niddah. When one hates another person, he keeps his distance from him. (that hate you) (Is. 66:5).

AND BE UNCLEAN UNTIL THE EVEN. Once Scripture states that the gatherer of the ashes shall wash his clothes there is no need to mention that he shall wash in water.24For Scripture earlier linked the two. See verse 7.
AND UNTO THE STRANGER THAT SOJOURNETH AMONG THEM. For the Land of Israel is holy because God’s glory is there.25Hence even a stranger (a non-Jew) must abide by this rule.
EVEN ANY MAN’S DEAD BODY. Be it the body of a Jew or a non-Jew.
MAN’S…BODY. Not the body of an animal.

SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The meaning of ve-tame is, shall be unclean. It is a future form, for the vav changes the verb26Tame, a third person perfect. from a perfect to an imperfect. However, I believe that ve-tame is in the past tense.27Its vav being conjunctive. Thus the meaning of ve-tame is: and he was unclean. The import of our verse thus is: and after being unclean for seven days he shall purify himself. See I.E. on verse 7 and the notes thereto.

THE SAME SHALL PURIFY HIMSELF THEREWITH. The meaning of hu yitchate vo (the same shall purify himself therewith) is, he shall remove his sin therewith.28That is, by undergoing this ritual he will remove the potentiality of entering the sanctuary in a state of impurity and thus sinning. The word chet means sin. Hence I.E.’s interpretation. On the other hand, the word yitchate (shall purify himself) is similar to the word techatteni (purge me) in Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean (Ps. 51:9).29In other words, yitchatta means purify. Those who are acquainted with the secret of numbers know that the number three is like the number seven.30The number seven has mystical significance in that seven days make up a lunar quarter. The number three is close to half of the number 7. See I.E. on Gen. 34:25 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 330).

BECAUSE THE WATER OF SPRINKLING. Some say that that me niddah (the water of sprinkling) has the same meaning as me niddah (water of sprinkling) in it shall be purified with the water of sprinkling (Num. 31:23).31In other words, both refer to water mixed with the ashes of the red heifer. Num. 31:23 deals with the purification of utensils captured from non-Jews. I.E. prefaces these remarks with “some say” because, according to the rabbis, Num. 31:23 refers to water in which a menstruant immerses herself.
WAS NOT DASHED. The word zorak (dashed) refers to the water.32Even though zorak is singular and me (water of) is plural.
IS YET. The word od (is yet) means continuously.33He is continuously unclean until sprinkled. Compare, od (while) in While the earth remaineth (Gen. 8:22).

IN A TENT. A house has the same law as a tent. Scripture mentions a tent because Israel then lived in tents. That killeth an ox, or lamb, or goat, in the camp (Lev. 17:3) is similar.34The law laid down in Lev. 17:3 applies equally to a town. Scripture speaks of a camp because Israel then lived in tents in a camp.
AND EVERY THING THAT IS IN THE TENT. Garments.35For the next verse deals with vessels.

COVERING CLOSE-BOUND. Two coverings.36Scripture reads, tzamid, petil (close bound). According to I.E. each one of these terms refers to a covering. The tzamid goes over the opening, while the petil goes round about the above covering and the rim of the utensil (Krinsky). Others claim that I.E. believes that the cover is made of two parts. See Krinsky, Filwarg, and Weiser.
OR A GRAVE. Of a human being.

AND FOR THE UNCLEAN THEY SHALL TAKE. See, Scripture explains how one who comes into contact with the dead shall purge himself.37Earlier, in verse 12, Scripture had said, the same shall purify himself therewith. However, it did not describe the procedure. Now it does.
A CLEAN PERSON. The reference is most probably to a kohen.38For kohanim are acquainted with the laws of purification.

BUT THE MAN THAT SHALL BE UNCLEAN. Scripture has already mentioned, Whosoever toucheth the dead…that soul shall be cut off from Israel (v. 13). It now warns the one who touches a bone or a grave [not to defile the sanctuary].
SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL EVEN. And shall not become clean until he washes.
AND WHATSOEVER THE UNCLEAN PERSON TOUCHETH SHALL BE UNCLEAN. The reference is to one who has become unclean by touching a dead body, a bone, or a grave.
SHALL BE UNCLEAN UNTIL EVEN. And washes.39Verse 7.

IN THE FIRST MONTH. In the fortieth year.1Following the Exodus. Look, the Torah does not contain any act or prophecy except in the first and the fortieth year.2Scripture describes what happened in the first and the last year of Israel’s sojourn in the wilderness. What happened in the other years is ignored. Actually the Book of Numbers opens with a command to Moses in the second month of the second year. Filwarg explains that I.E. was not being precise. Some editions read, “except for the first year, the fortieth year.” The latter is to be interpreted as if written, and the fortieth year.

[AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL, EVEN THE WHOLE CONGREGATION, CAME.] Scripture states this because the generation that left Egypt died in the wilderness and they who were entering Canaan came to the desert of Zin.3The phrase even the whole congregation appears to be unnecessary. I.E. says that it refers to those about to enter Canaan. They are now the complete congregation, for none of them need die in the wilderness. Rashi comments similarly.

AND THE PEOPLE ABODE IN KADESH. For they dwelt there for many days.4Scripture states, and the people abode in Kadesh, because they dwelt there for many days. The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.5See Deut. 1:46, So ye abode in Kadesh many days.

AND THERE WAS NO WATER FOR THE CONGREGATION. Scripture tells of two incidents.6That happened in Kadesh. One, the death of Miriam. Two, the death of Aaron and Moses and their failure to enter the land.7I.E. considers this one incident, for the latter was dependent upon the former. It begins by telling the cause of the latter.
AND THE PEOPLE STROVE. Va-yarev (strove) is a hifil.
WHEN OUR BRETHREN PERISHED. Bi-geva (when…perished) is an infinitive. It is similar to ki-shekav (when…shall sleep) in when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers (I Kings 1:21).

OUR BRETHREN. The generation that died in the desert. They were servants of the Lord.8Scripture states, our brethren perished. Why add, before the Lord? According to I.E., before the Lord indicates that they worshipped the Lord.
AND WHY HAVE YE BROUGHT. This was addressed to Moses and Aaron, for Scripture goes on to say, and they assembled themselves together against Moses and against Aaron (v. 2).
Scripture reads, And the people strove with Moses, (v. 3) because their quarrel with Moses was more intense.9Than their quarrel with Aaron.
HAVE YE MADE US TO COME UP. He’elitunu (have ye made us to come up) is irregular.10Although this form is grammatically correct, it is not employed in Scripture (Weiser).

AND MOSES AND AARON WENT11Hebrew, va-yavo’u. This literally means, and they came. FROM THE PRESENCE OF THE ASSEMBLY. Like those who flee.12Our verse is to be rendered, And Moses and Aaron fled from the presence of the assembly. I.E. interprets thus because Scripture reads, from the presence (mi-pene) of the assembly. I.E. believes that the latter indicates that they fled.
AND FELL UPON THEIR FACES. To pray. Other interpret, to prophetically inquire of God.

TAKE THE ROD. Many interpretations are offered for this incident.13The sin of Moses and Aaron. There is an individual opinion that Moses sinned because he said to Israel, who are the children of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob: Hear now, ye rebels (v. 10). However, if this were the case why did he again say,14After being punished. ye have been rebellious against the Lord (Deut. 9:7). Others say that the word ve-dibbartem (and speak ye) has the meaning, and ye shall strike. It is similar to the word va-tedabber (and destroyed) in and destroyed all the seed royal (II Chron. 22:10). However, this is incorrect, for va-tedabber is related to the word dever (destruction) or to the word yadber (he subdueth) in He subdueth peoples under us (Ps. 47:4). Va-tedabber15In II Chron. 22:10. thus means, and destroyed. Indeed, it so reads in the other book.16Its parallel in the Book of Kings. We read there, and destroyed (va-te’abbed) all the seed royal (II Kings 11:1). The meaning of ve-dibbartem el ha-sela (and speak ye unto the rock) thus is,17According to this interpretation. and ye shall destroy the rock.18Not, and you shall hit the rock. Furthermore, if this is the meaning of the word,19If ve-dibbartem means, and you shall strike. why was Moses punished? The above commentaries answer, because he hit the rock twice. However, if this is the case why was Aaron punished?20Aaron did not strike the rock. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard, of blessed memory, says that some signs21Miracles. are performed by word of mouth, others by action and speech, as in the case of the salt22Some editions read millat (the incident of). which Elisha cast into the water.23And he (Elisha) went forth unto the spring of the waters, and cast salt therein, and said, Thus saith the Lord: I have healed these waters; there shall be not be from thence any more death or miscarrying, (II Kings 2:21). God commanded Moses to take the staff and strike the rock as he did in the case of the rock [at Horeb].24See Ex. 17:6. He added the word ve-dibbartem (and speak ye)25In our case. so that the water would flow via the speech and the blow. Because Israel angered him, Moses said, are we to bring you forth water from the rock? What Moses meant26By are we to bring you forth water out of the rock? was, we do not have the power to bring water out of the rock. We can only do so by the power of God. Now Moses did not make himself clear. People thought what he said was that God cannot bring water out of the rock. This is the meaning of because ye sanctified Me not in the midst of the children of Israel (Deut. 32:51). Rabbi Moses offered proof from the words of the poet who said, For they embittered his spirit, And he spoke rashly with his lip (Ps. 106:33). The sin was thus in his expressing, not by striking [the rock]. However, this too is incorrect, for Moses said, are we to bring you forth water out of this rock (v. 10). Why was Aaron punished?27If Moses didn’t make himself understood. Furthermore, no speech is mentioned in the Torah’s description of the act of striking the rock.28Thus a verbal pronouncement was not part of this event. The proof offered29From Ps. 106:33. by Rabbi Moses is no proof because the meaning of For they embittered his spirit is that they embittered God’s spirit. Scripture similarly writes, But they rebelled, and grieved His holy spirit (Is. 63:10). This is the meaning of They angered Him also at the waters of Meribah (Ps. 106:32). It means they angered God.30In other words, “him” refers to God, not to Moses. Scripture similarly states, These are the waters of Meribah, where the children of Israel strove with the Lord (Num. 20:13).31Thus “him” in they angered Him also at the waters of Meribah, refers to God. Scripture says, And it went ill with Moses because of them (Ps. 106:32) because they embittered God’s spirit, and He decreed that Moses not enter the land.32I.E.’s interpretation of Ps. 106:32. Others say that the meaning of speak to the rock can only mean strike the rock, for a rock cannot hear.33I.E. appears to be referring to Rashbam. It should be noted that Rashbam answers I.E.’s question. Now if this is so, why was Moses punished?34He did what he was instructed to, viz., to strike the rock. Some say that Moses and Aaron were punished because they did not sing a song of praise35Unto the Lord for giving them water. as in Spring up, O well-sing ye unto it (Num. 21:17). They say that this is the meaning of because ye sanctified Me not (Deut. 32:51).36Its meaning is, you did not sing a song of praise to me. Others say that God commanded Moses and Aaron to speak to the rock, but they did not speak to it. On the contrary, Moses struck the rock.37This is the opinion of Rashi. See Rashi on verse 11.
His interpretation is in keeping with the literal meaning of the text. Therefore they were both punished and they were told, ye trespassed (Deut. 32:51); ye rebelled (v. 24); ye believed not in Me (v. 12), and ye sanctified Me not (Deut. 32:52). Those who are guided by reason38And do not take Scripture literally when it is opposes reason. say that it is impossible that a messenger of God would alter God’s word.39If God told Moses to speak to the rock, then Moses would not strike the rock. If Moses transformed God’s word, how can we believe his Torah?40What assurance do we have that Moses did not alter the Torah? However, the aforementioned41Those who said that God told Moses to speak to the rock but that he struck the rock. also spoke incorrectly, for if Moses had altered a commandment he would have been punished immediately.42Moses was not punished immediately. His punishment was delayed. Look, Moses was punished with regard to something which was not an eternal commandment and not a law given to Israel. Nor did he knowingly violate God’s command. He only did so inadvertently because Israel angered him. Moses clearly said, Also the Lord was angry with me for your sakes (Deut. 1:37).43Which shows that he was not punished for deliberately violating God’s command. Others say that Israel told Moses44The text does not state this. These commentaries assume it. to bring water out of a different rock.45Than the one he was commanded to speak to. They offer this rock as proof (v. 10).46Are we to bring you forth water out of this rock? implies that we cannot bring water out of this rock, but we can out of another, that is, the rock about which God commanded us. However, Moses was afraid to alter God’s word.47For this was not the rock he was commanded to strike. Moses was punished because he did not believe that he would be able to bring forth water from the rock that Israel chose. He was therefore punished.48For not striking the rock chosen by Israel. This is the meaning of ye believed not in Me (v. 12). This interpretation is also incorrect, for Scripture states, ye rebelled against My word (v. 24). However, they did not rebel.49For they struck the rock which God commanded them to strike.I will reveal in hints the explanation which appears correct to me. Know, when the part50A person. knows the All,51I.E. often refers to God as the All. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 47). God is the creator of all. He is all. Also see I.E. on Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 695). he cleaves to the All and creates signs and wonders with the help of the All.52See I.E. on Ex. 33:21 (Vol. 2, p. 695). Now it is true that God told Moses and Aaron, speak ye unto the rock. They did not speak to the rock because the people were quarreling with Moses. The “part” thus remained a “part.”53Moses was distracted and his mind did not cleave unto God. He struck the rock, and water did not come out of it54Because he was not cleaving unto God. until he struck it a second time.55His anger having been assuaged, Moses now cleaved unto God (Krinsky). This explanation is difficult. If Moses’ anger was assuaged, why didn’t he now speak to the rock? Moses and Aaron thus did not sanctify God’s name. They inadvertently rebelled and trespassed. It is also possible to explain that And he spoke rashly with his lips (Ps. 106:33) refers to Moses.56And not to God as previously explained. It was unseemly for Moses to say anything57Such as Hear now, ye rebels, etc. (v. 10). before fulfilling God’s command. Moses was therefore punished. The midrashic interpretation of our ancients, of blessed memory, who said that Moses sinned because he said, Hear now, ye rebels (v. 10) is also in keeping with this interpretation. The rabbis hint at this secret.
UNTO THE ROCK. Which I pointed out to you or which is found close to the camp.58Hence Scripture speaks of the rock and not of a rock.

THAT IT GIVE FORTH ITS WATER. Many erred and said that the rock is to be identified with the stone [at Horeb]59Ex. 17:6. because Scripture reads, its water.60Rather than water. These commentaries assume that its water indicates that the stone had already produced water. See Bahya and Da’at zekenim mi-ba’ale ha-tosafot. However, they cannot think straight. The stone was in Horeb and this rock was at the border of the land of Edom, for it was in Kadesh.61See verses 1 and 14. It is also possible to interpret its water as meaning, the water which I will place in it.
THE ROD FROM BEFORE THE LORD. The reference is to the rod of God.62See Ex. 4:20. It was the rod which was placed before the testimony.63Num. 17:1-24.
ARE WE TO BRING YOU FORTH WATER OUT OF THIS ROCK? Do we have the power to bring forth water out of this rock for you?
BECAUSE YE BELIEVED NOT IN ME. This alludes to the secret at which I hinted, i.e., that God’s name was not sanctified through them.

AND HE WAS SANCTIFIED IN THEM. Through Moses and Aaron.64In other words, the term bam (in them) does not refer to the water. Our verse has the same meaning as Through them that are nigh unto Me I will be sanctified (Lev. 10:3).65God is sanctified when he punishes the righteous. See Rashi.

FROM KADESH. Kadesh is the name of a place where a city is located. It is not to be identified with Kadesh-barnea,66Deut. 1:2,19; 2:14; 9:23. for the latter was a wilderness.67See Deut. 1:19. Thus Scripture reads, The Lord shaketh the wilderness of Kadesh (Ps. 29:8).68I.E. assumes that the reference is to Kadesh-barnea, for Kadesh-barnea, unlike Kadesh, was a wilderness. However, his reasoning is circular.
THE TRAVAIL. I have already explained the meaning of the word tela’ah (travail).69See I.E. on Ex. 18:8 (Vol. 2, p. 353): “Its meaning is, an affliction which a person is unable to bear or verbalize.”

EGYPTIANS DEALT ILL WITH US, AND OUR FATHERS. Who died. The meaning of our clause is that their evil70The evil which the Egyptians did to us, for they afflicted us and our parents. lasted a very long time.

AND SENT AN ANGEL.71Hebrew, malakh. The word malakh can be rendered as messenger or angel. Hence I.E.’s comment. This is to be taken literally. Scripture similarly states, And the angel of His presence saved them (Is. 63:9). Many said that the reference is to Moses72See Rashi. for they found Then spoke Haggai the Lord’s messenger (malakh)73We thus see that Scripture refers to a prophet by the term malakh. (Haggai 1:13). However, this is not my opinion.
THROUGH FIELD OR THROUGH VINEYARD. So that they do not destroy it. We will not even drink the water of your wells.

WE WILL GO ALONG THE KING’S HIGHWAY. The major highway upon which the king travels. Or its meaning is, the road that the king, namely, the king of Edom, will command us to travel in.74According to this interpretation the meaning of our verse is: we will go on any road which you the king will choose for us to travel on.
WE WILL GO UP BY THE HIGHWAY. What harm will it cause you if we up by the highway? If we need water you will sell it to us. This is the meaning of mikhram (v. 19). It means the price thereof.

[THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] Its meaning is, the entire congregation. Because Edom went to fight against them, Scripture relates that no one was missing from the children of Israel when they came from the city of Edom to Mount Hor.75In other words, no Jews were killed by the Edomites.

AARON SHALL BE GATHERED UNTO HIS PEOPLE. This is similar to and die in the mount (Deut. 32:50).76The meaning of which is: and prepare yourself to die, for it is not in one’s hand to determine the moment of death. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, p. 47). It means that Aaron should prepare himself to die, and go up the mountain.77Aaron shall be gathered unto his people means Aaron shall go and be gathered to his people.
YE HAVE REBELLED. I have explained this.

AT THE WATERS OF MERIBAH. Le-me merivah means at the waters of Meribah.78A lamed prefixed to a word means to. Thus le-me meribah might be taken to mean to the water of Meribah. Hence I.E.’s comment. It is the name of a place. Or le-me merivah means because of the waters of Meribah.79See previous note.
AND STRIP…AND PUT THEM UPON. Ve-hafshet (and strip) and ve-hilbashtam (and put them upon) are hifils.
[AND AARON SHALL BE GATHERED.] Its meaning is, as soon as you strip Aaron of his garments, he shall die.

AND AARON WAS GATHERED TO HIS PEOPLE.80This is not in the Biblical text. Our reading in I.E. is probably a scribal error. I have explained this.81The meaning of the word gathered. See I.E. on Gen. 25:8 (Vol. 1, p. 246).

AND WHEN ALL THE CONGREGATION SAW. When they saw the event which occurred, they wept for thirty days.82In other words, And all the congregation saw (the literal interpretation of the verse) is to be rendered, And when all the congregation saw.
[DIED.] I have already explained the meaning of the term.83See I.E. on Gen. 25:8 (Vol. 1, p. 245): “Gava refers to a death wherein the soul leaves the body in a moment without pain and delay.”

AND THE CANAANITE, THE KING OF ARAD. The ancients1The sages of the Talmud. said he2The king of Arad. See Rosh Ha-Shanah 3a: “Sihon, Arad, and Canaan are one and the same.” is Sihon. He is called a Canaanite, for all Amorites are Canaanites.3Sihon was king of the Amorites. See verse 21. Many say that Joshua wrote this section.4Verses 1-3. The king of Arad, one (Josh. 12:14) is proof of this.5Josh. 12 lists the kings that Joshua smote. The king of Arad is included in this list. It thus appears that it was Joshua, not Moses, who defeated the king of Arad. They also found that Scripture states that the children of Judah called the name of the place Hormah.6In the days of Joshua. See Josh. 12:14. However, they are wrong, for that place7The Hormah spoken of in Josh. 12:14. was originally called Zephath8See Jud. 1:17: And Judah went with Simeon his brother, and they smote the Canaanites that inhabited Zephath, and utterly destroyed it. And the name of the city was called Hormah. while the place spoken of in our verse was ruled by the king of Arad.9It was always called Arad. In reality they are two places.10The Hormah mentioned in our verse is not to be identified with the Hormah in Josh. 12:14. There are many such instances in Scripture.11Of two places having the same name. According to the plain meaning of the text the king of Arad ruled over the eastern bank of the Jordan.12And was thus defeated by Moses. This portion13Verses 1-3. was connected to the death of Aaron, because Scripture relates what happened on Mount Hor14The place of Aaron’s death. before they [Israel] journeyed from there. And the Canaanite, the king of Arad… heard…and they journeyed from mount Hor (v. 4) is proof of this.15That the king of Arad fought Israel at Mount Hor. If you want to find what the king of Arad heard, observe, it is clearly stated.16The king heard that Israel came by the way of Atharim (v. 1).

THAT ISRAEL CAME BY THE WAY OF ATHARIM. Some say that the alef of atharim is superfluous. They say that the meaning of ha-atharim is, those who spy. The alef of ezro’akha (your arm) is similar.17For the meaning of ezro’akha is, your arm (zero’akha). The reference is probably to Jer. 32:21. However, the text there reads ezro’a.

TO COMPASS THE LAND OF EDOM. Zalmonah and Punon, for this is explicitly stated in Scripture.18See Num. 33:41-45. Scripture here omits the places where Israel camped when they compassed the land of Edom. It does include them in Num. 33:41-45. It tells us there that Israel camped at Zalmonah and Punon when it went around Edom.

THIS LIGHT BREAD. The word ha-kelokel (this light) means the very light. The word is formed by doubling the word kal.19Kelokel is an intensified form. Hence the meaning very light. There are many similar instances in Scripture.20Compare, adamdam (very red), shecharhar (very black).

AND THE LORD…SERPENTS. The word ha-serafim (fiery) is an adjective. The following is a midrashic interpretation. Scripture states, If the serpent bite before it is charmed, Then the charmer hath no advantage (Eccles. 10:11). These people21Who spoke against God and Moses. sent their tongues to bite.22A metaphor for speaking evil. They were repaid with snakes being sent against them.
MAKE THEE. A form of a fiery serpent out of brass, for Scripture explicitly says so.23In the next verse.

AND SET IT UPON A POLE. So that it be on a high place and everyone will be able to see it. Many err. They say that this was an image that had the capability of receiving powers from on high.24It was an image in whom heavenly power resided and thus could heal those bitten by the serpents. See I.E. on Gen. 31:19 (Vol. 1, p. 300) and Ex. 20:20 (Vol. 2, p. 437). According to I.E. such an image is banned by Scripture for it is a type of magical practice. Far be it, far be it [for one to believe such a thing], for this thing was made by God’s command.25God would not command such an object to be made. According to I.E. this is precisely what Ex. 20:20 prohibits. See I.E. on Ex. 20:20 (Vol. 2, p. 437). We should not investigate why Moses was commanded to make the form of a snake.26And argue that there is a scientific reason for the copper snake. Should someone disagree,27Those who offer scientific explanations. let him show us if there is a tree that makes bitter waters sweet.28Moses healed bitter waters by casting a tree into it. See Ex. 15:22-25. Even honey will not sweeten them.29Bitter water. What reason was there to put a cake of figs upon a boil?30When King Hezekiah was ill with boils the prophet Isaiah prescribed that a cake of figs be applied to his boils. See II Kings 20:7; Is. 38:21. It is not in the nature of figs to remove boils. The truth is that the mind of the Almighty is beyond us.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED. From the land of Edom, for Scripture states, to compass the land of Edom (v. 4). Punon31See I.E. on verse 4. is on the far border of Edom. The Israelites traveled from Punon to Oboth, for Scripture says so.32Num. 33:43.
AND PITCHED IN THE VALLEY OF ZERED. Zered is elsewhere referred to as Dibon-gad.33In Num. 33:45. The purpose of I.E.’s comments on verses 4, 10, and 12 is to harmonize our chapter with Num. 33.
FOR ARNON IS THE BORDER OF MOAB. It was so at first.34Before Israel conquered Sihon.

IN THE BOOK OF THE WARS OF THE LORD. It was a separate book in which the wars of the Lord on behalf of His servants was recorded. It is possible that it originated in the days of Abraham,35The first servant of God to wage war. See Gen. 14:13-16. for many books, such as the work of Nathan36See I Chron. 29:29. and Iddo,37II Chron. 12:15. the chronicles of the kings of Israel,38I Kings 14:19. and the songs of Solomon and his proverbs,39I Kings 5:12. were lost and are not found among us.

VAHEB IN SUPHAH. There were wars in these mentioned places in ancient times. The word Vaheb is not Hebrew. Neither is Vophsi (Num. 13:14), Vashti (Esth. 1:9), Vaizatha (Esth. 9:9), and also Vashni (I Chron. 6:13). It is possible that the vav of Vashni is a connective.40In this case, the meaning of Vashni is, and sheni (sheni being a Hebrew name). I say all this41That these words are not Hebrew. because we do not find the vav to be a root letter at the beginning of a word42In other words, we do not find the vav to be a first root letter. except in the word vave (hooks) in the hooks of the pillars (Ex. 27:10). It is found43As a first root letter. only in place of a yod. Compare, valed (child) (II Sam. 6:23).44Which comes from the root yod, lamed, dalet. The explanation of the Aramaic translation is known.45Onkelos renders sufah (Suphah) as yama de-suf (the sea of reeds).

AND THE SLOPE OF THE VALLEYS. Some say that the word eshed (slope) is Aramaic.46Rashi claims that the word eshed means pouring or spilling in Aramaic. The end of the matter is: all of these47Vaheb, Suphah, Eshed, etc. are names of places.48In other words, eshed is the name of a place.
THAT INCLINETH. The reference is to the Israelites,49Israel inclined towards the city of Ar. for they passed by Ar.50Israel passed by the city of Ar. They did not enter it. See Deut. 2:9.

AND LEANETH UPON THE BORDER OF MOAB. This is what and they51Israel. abide over against me52This was said by the king of the Moabites. (Num. 22:5) refers to. Israel journeyed from there53The border of Moab. to a place called be’er, for the heh of be’erah (to Beer) is in place of the word el (to). It is like the heh of mitzraymah (to Egypt) (Gen. 12 :10).54Which is in place of the word el. This well55Spoken of in verse 16. was also56Like the manna, the waters of Marah, and the like. the result of a miracle. I believe that it is not the well which is called Miriam’s well.57Contrary to the opinion of the rabbis. See Ta’anit 9a. On the contrary, it refers to a place that Moses commanded to be dug. The princes of Israel dug it with their staffs, and water immediately gushed forth.
SPRING UP, O WELL. This is how the song opened. Scripture does not record the entire song.
SING YE UNTO IT. The word enu (sing) is an imperative. Note, Scripture explains58In verse 18. how it came into being.59Princes and nobles dug the well.
WHICH THE NOBLES OF THE PEOPLE DELVED. Scripture repeats itself,60Which the nobles…delved repeats which the princes digged. as is its style.

WITH THE SCEPTRE. The meaning of bi-mechokek (with the sceptre) is, by the governors.61The bet of bi-mechokek means by. The bet usually has the meaning of in. Hence I.E.’s comment. Compare, My heart is toward the governors (chokeke) of Israel (Jud. 5:9). This well was in the wilderness, far from an inhabited place. From this wilderness Israel journeyed to Mattanah. From Mattanah they journeyed to Nahaliel. Note that eshed ha-nehalim (the slope of the valleys) and the wilderness which is called Beer and Mattanah and Nahaliel are all names of places. They are also referred to by a general name, viz., Almon-diblathiam (Num. 33:46), which is found in the Torah portion Ve-Elleh Mase (Ibid.).62Which records the journeys of the children of Israel in the wilderness. Eshed ha-nehalim (the slope of the valleys), Beer, Mattanah, and Nahaliel are not mentioned there. Almon-diblathiam is. Hence I.E.’s comment. On the other hand, it is also possible that these are the names of places that the Israelites passed over in another journey.63Hence they are not recorded in Num. 33:46. The mountains of Abarim in front of Nebo (Num. 33:47) are to be identified with Bamoth and the valley that is in the field of Moab (v. 20). The following is proof of this. Scripture states that Israel journeyed from the valley64That is in the field of Moab (v. 10). to the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho (Num. 22:1).65I.E. connects Num. 22:1 to Num. 21:10. It also states that Israel journeyed from the mountains of Abarim to the plains of Moab beyond the Jordon at Jericho (Num. 33:48). It further states, So we abode in the valley66Which is in the field of Moab. over against Beth-peor (Deut. 3:29) at the time that I [Moses] pleaded [with God].67To allow him to enter Canaan. This was shortly before Moses’ death. Scripture elsewhere states, Get thee up into this mountain of Abarim, unto mount Nebo (Deut. 32:49).68We thus see that Moses went up to Mount Nebo from the valley which is the field of Moab. Scripture also states, and he was buried in the valley (Deut. 34:6). The Torah there states, And Moses went up from the plains of Moab unto mount Nebo to the top of Pisgah (Deut. 34:1). The valley was thus at the top of Pisgah. Moses died there, and there was no need to move him after his death.69As would be the case if the “valley” where Moses died was not at the top of the mountain. According to I.E. the “valley” was an indentation at the top of the mountain.
WHICH LOOKETH DOWN. Ve-nishkafah (which looketh down) is in the feminine. It refers to the valley.70The word guy (valley) can be masculine or feminine.

UPON THE DESERT. The word yeshimon (desert) means a wasteland (shemamah). And in the waste, a howling wilderness (yeshimon) (Deut. 32:10) is the proof text. So too is They wandered in the wilderness (yeshimon) in a desert way (Ps. 107:4).
TO JAHAZ. Yahtzah means to Jahaz.71The heh at the end of the word is in place of the preposition to.
FROM THE ARNON. Which he [the king of Edom] took from Moab.

EVEN UNTO THE CHILDREN OF AMMON. Scripture records that half of the land of Ammon belonged to the children of Israel,72Josh. 13:24,25. for they73The Israelites. took it from the Amorites who originally took it from the children of Ammon. Now Scripture tells us that God would not give the Israelites even the size of a footstep from any of the land belonging to the Ammonites and Moabites. The reference is to the land which Ammon and Moab possessed at that time.74In the time of Moses. Scripture therefore had to record the words of the poets.75To the effect that Sihon took the city of Heshbon from the Moabites. It did so because Israel lived in Heshbon.76Which was originally a Moabite city. The Torah explicitly states, And Israel dwelt in all the cities of the Amorite, in Heshbon77We thus see that Israel dwelt in Heshbon. (v. 25).
AND IN ALL THE TOWNS THEREOF.78Literally, and in all her daughters. Heshbon is like a mother, and the towns are like daughters.79Thus, “and in all her daughters” means: and in all the towns thereof.

FOR HESHBON WAS THE CITY OF SIHON. It turned into the city of Sihon, for, as was well known, he fought against the former king of Moab.80Scripture speaks of Sihon’s victory over Moab as a well-known fact.
THEY THAT SPEAK IN PARABLES. Who invent parables on their own.81The literal meaning of ha-moshelim (they that speak in parables) is the parablers.
[COME YE TO HESHBON.] They said this to the Amorites.
BE BUILT. Better than before.
AND ESTABLISHED. To be the city of Sihon.
FOR A FIRE IS GONE OUT OF HESHBON. This alludes to the people of Heshbon who conspired against their king.82According to I.E. our verse teaches that Moabites conspired against their king.
A FLAME. The idea is repeated in accord with poetic style.83A flame…repeats For a fire…
FROM THE CITY OF SIHON. From the city that today belongs to Sihon.
AR OF MOAB. Ar is the name of a place. It is in Moab.84The Hebrew reads ar mo’av. Compare, Beth-lehem Judah85Translated literally. See I.E. on Num. 13:22. (Ruth 1:1).
THE HIGH PLACES. Bamot means the high places.86It is not the name of a place.
CHEMOSH. The name of an idol; Moab’s god.
FUGITIVES. Those who flee. Fugitives that run from the sword.

WE HAVE SHOT THEM. These are the words of Moses.87Until now Scripture records what the poets said. Now it records the comments of Moses. The mem of va-niram88A pronominal suffix meaning them. (we shot at them) refers to the king of the Amorites and his troops. It has two interpretations. One, that va-niram is related to the word nir (kingship). It89The word nir. is to be read as if written twice.90Our verse, which reads va-niram avad cheshbon (we have shot at them—Heshbon is perished), is to be read, va-niram avad nir cheshbon (and their king, the king of Heshbon, was destroyed). It is like even the prophecy, Oded the prophet (II Chron. 15:8).91Which is to be read as if written, even the prophecy, the prophecy of Oded the prophet. See I.E. on Gen. 6:13 (Vol. 1, p. 100) and the notes thereto. Our verse means, and their king the king of Heshbon was destroyed. Va-niram is similar to the word ha-oholi (my tent) in in the midst of my tent (Josh. 7:21), and to ha-erkekha (thy valuation) (Lev. 27:23).92The pattach beneath the vav is the sign of the direct object. In other words, va-niram is short for ve-ha-niram. Thus va-niram is similar to ha-oholi and ha-erkekha in that both words are written with the direct object even though they have suffixes. Words with suffixes usually do not come with the direct object. Hence I.E.’s comment. Va-niram avad cheshbon (we have shot at them—Heshbon is perished) means, their king, that is, the king of Heshbon, perished. Second, that va-niram is related to yereh va-yor (shoot; and he shot) (II Kings 13:17) and yariti (cast)93Translated literally. (Gen. 31:51). It means,94Va-niram avad heshbon (we have shot at them–Heshbon is perished). when we shot them Heshbon was destroyed.

AND WE HAVE LAID WASTE. Va-nashim comes from a double root.95Even though it is spelled with one mem. It comes from the root shin, mem, mem. The chirik is in place of a short kamatz.96A tzere. In other words, the word should have been vocalized va-nashem. Compare, va-yasev (led about) in But God led the people about (Ex. 13:18).97Which is vocalized with a tzere. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the dagesh in the shin of va-nashim compensates for a missing alef.98According to Rabbi Moses, va-nashim comes from the root alef, shin, mem (guilty). Compare, Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth (Job. 35:11) wherein an alef is missing in the word mallefenu (teacheth us).99Which comes from the root alef, lamed, peh. The word va-nashim is related to the word tesham100In other words, it comes from the root alef, shin, mem. (shall bear her guilt) in Samaria shall bear her guilt (Hos. 14:1). Some say that Heshbon was always the city of Sihon.101See I.E. on verses 26-28. In this case, Come ye to Heshbon (v. 27) is the line that the poets directed at the Moabites who came as captive to Heshbon. And for a fire is gone out of Heshbon is a metaphor for the army of Sihon. When the poets speak on behalf of the Moabites, they say, we thought that Heshbon will be destroyed102They interpret our verse as follows: We (the Moabites) shot at them. W e thought Heshbon is perished…even unto Nophah. and the entire land will be laid waste even unto Nophah. Or these103We have shot at them…unto Nophah (v. 30). are the words of Moses.
AND THEY TURNED. I have already explained its meaning.104The meaning of va-yifnu (and they turned). See I.E. on Ex. 10:6 (Vol. 2, p. 186). I.E. explains there that va-yifnu means, and they faced.
EDREI. To Edrei. Scripture is being brief.105In omitting the preposition el (to).

NONE LEFT HIM REMAINING. No one of the Israelites.106The verse literally reads, until he left (hishir) him [Og] no remainder. Since the first part of the verse is in the plural, our clause should have read, until they left (hishiru) him no remainder. Hence I.E.’s comment.

TO THE AMORITES. The lamed prefixed to the word emori (Amorite) is vocalized with a kamatz.1A lamed so vocalized indicates the definite article. Its reference is to the famous Amorites Sihon and Og. There were no kings among the Canaanites as great as they. Whose height was like the height of the cedars (Amos 2:9) is proof of this.2The entire verse reads: Yet I destroyed the Amorite [Sihon and Og] before them, Whose height was like the height of the cedars (Amos 2:9).
AND MOAB WAS SORE AFRAID. Va-yagar means was afraid. Guru lakhem (be ye afraid) (Job 19:29) is similar.

AND MOAB WAS OVERCOME WITH DREAD. Va-yakatz (overcome with dread) has the same meaning as a similarly spelled word whose letters are inverted.3Va-yatzak. Va-yatzak is spelled vav, yod, tzadi, kof. Va-yakatz is spelled vav, yod, kof, tzadi. U-nekitzennah (and vex it) in Let us go up against Judah, and vex it (Is. 7:6) is similar.
UNTO THE ELDERS OF MIDIAN. It is possible that the five Midianite kings are these same elders.4Num. 31:8 speaks of five Midianite kings. I.E. identifies the elders in our verse with them.

NOW WILL THIS MULTITUDE LICK UP…AS THE OX LICKETH UP. Yelachakhu (will…lick up) and ki-lechokh (as…licketh up) are two different conjugations.5Yelachakhu (will…lick up) is in the pi’el. Ki-lechokh (as…licketh up) is a kal. Both words come from the root lamed, chet, caf.
TO PETHOR. Pethorah means to Pethor.6The heh at the end of the word is in place of the preposition to. Compare, mitzrayemah (to Egypt) (Gen. 37:25).

TO THE LAND OF THE CHILDREN OF HIS PEOPLE. Who were Arameans. Scripture similarly states, from Pethor of Aram-naharaim (Deut. 23:5). The midrash7See San. 105a. Also see Targum Jonathan on Gen. 36:32. identifies Balaam with Bela.8An Edomite king mentioned in Gen. 36:32. [However, the identification is untenable] because Balaam was an Aramean. If we identify Balaam with Bela because of Beor his father,9Both Bela and Balaam had a father called be’or. then, lo and behold, the son of Ahasuerus10Darius. See Dan. 9:1. lived before Ahasuerus.11Esth. 1:1. I.E.’s point is that names alone cannot serve to identify historical figures, for more than one person have the same name. According to the midrash (Esther Rabbah 1:1), King Ahasuerus mentioned in the Book of Esther had a son called Darius. There was also a King Darius who lived before Ahasuerus mentioned in the book of Esther. If every Darius in the Bible is one and the same person, then Darius son of Ahasuerus lived before Ahasuerus his father. See I.E. on Dan. 9:1 and Esth. 1:1. They12Bela and Balaam. are definitely two different people.
WHICH IS BY THE RIVER. The reference is to Aram-naharaim.
THE FACE OF THE EARTH. I have already explained the meaning of this expression.13This is to be taken metaphorically. See I.E. on Ex. 10:5 (Vol. 2, p. 186).

CURSE ME. The word arah (curse) is an imperative. It comes from a double root with one of the double letters missing. The same is true of with the word kavah (curse) in curse me (v. 18). The word kov (curse) is vocalized according to the paradigm of shemor (keep).14It is vocalized with a cholam. Kavah15Kavah is an elongated form of kav. in kavah li (curse me) minus the heh16Pronounced kav. follows the paradigm of shechav (lie), rekhav (ride), and tzelach (rested on).17They are all vocalized with a pattach.

THAT WE MAY SMITE THEM. Nakkeh (that we may smite them)18From the root nun, caf, heh. is an infinitive. The fact that it ends in a heh is no argument against the latter,19The heh changes to a tav in the infinitive in words ending in a heh. Thus our word should have read le-nakkot. Hence I.E.’s comment. for the word le-khalle20From the root caf, lamed, heh. (to finish), in to finish the transgression (Dan. 9:24) is similar.21It too is an infinitive, and Scripture employs the form le-khalle rather than the more usual form le-khallot.

IS CURSED. The silent vav of yu’ar (is cursed) is in place of a dagesh, which is in place of the missing double letter.22The root of yu’ar is alef, resh, resh. Yu’ar is spelled with only one resh. Compare, yusav23Yusav and yu’ar are both pu’als. (turned about)24Yusav comes from the root samekh, bet, bet. In I.E.’s version of Scripture, unlike our versions, it does not have a dagesh. in turned about upon the cummin (Is. 28:27). There is no other word like it in this form, because of the rules concerning gutturals.25The alef. A guttural according to the rules of grammar does not receive a dagesh.
THE ELDERS OF MOAB. The wise men.26The elders were wise men (Weiser).

WITH THE REWARDS OF DIVINATION IN THEIR HAND. Rabbi Samuel Ha-Nagid the Sephardi, of blessed memory, said that the meaning of u-kesamim (with the reward of divination)27Balaam was the diviner, not the messengers sent to him. Hence Rabbi Samuel’s interpretation. is payment for divination. He offers as proof the word be-yadam (in their hand).28Rabbi Samuel believed that in their hand refers to the money which they brought with them for the divination. However, he says nothing. U-kesamim be-yadam is to be taken literally.29It refers to instruments of divination. Scripture tells us that Balak sent diviners like himself to the diviner [Balaam]. Furthermore, Balaam would not be able to tarry, saying, “I can not find a propitious day, and a propitious hour to go and curse,” for the messengers were members of his guild. In his right hand is the instrument of divination30Translated literally. (ha-kesom) (Ez. 21:27) is proof that u-kesamim be-yadam is to be taken literally.31For the verse shows that instruments of divination were held in the hand.
AND I WILL BRING YOU BACK WORD. After you spend the night here.

AND GOD CAME. Out of regard for Israel, for God knew the coming incident of ba’al pe’or.32A Moabite god worshipped by the Israelites. Twenty-four thousand Israelites died for worshipping this idol. See Num. 25:1-9. Now if Balaam had cursed them then, all of the world would have said that the plague came because of Balaam’s curse.33Otherwise God would have allowed Balaam to curse Israel, for his curse would not have had any effect.

WHAT MEN ARE THESE. This was a way of opening and starting a conversation.34God knew who the men were. It is similar to Where is Abel thy brother (Gen. 4:9). Now Cain denied [knowledge of Abel’s whereabouts]. However, God told him, the voice of thy brother’s blood crieth out unto Me (Gen. 4 :10).35Thus God knew where Abel was. Hence, Where is Abel thy brother was merely a way of starting a conversation.
FOR THEY ARE BLESSED. Its meaning is, you cannot curse them, for I have blessed them.

THE PRINCES OF BALAK. Scripture does not mention the elders of Midian,36See verse 4 and 7. for Balak was the protagonist and he sent the messengers to Balaam. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen the Spaniard, of blessed memory, says that even though the yod is the sign of the object37When suffixed to a verb, as in titti (give me). it can only come with a nun.38That is, the suffix ni has to be added to the verb in order to indicate the object. Compare, ha-lehorgeni (thinkest thou to kill me) (Ex. 2:14). It does not read ha-lehorgi. However, he forgot le-titti (to give me) in to give me leave to go with you [our verse] and yabbemi (perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto me) in he will not perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto me (Deut. 25:7).39In both of these words the object is indicated by the yod alone. Rabbi Jonah the grammarian says that the yod of le-titti40In other words, le-titti means the same as la-tet. It means to give, not to give me. is superfluous, but what he says is incorrect.41For the absence of the nun does not mean that the object (me) is missing.
[TO COME WITH US.]42Literally, to go with us. Hence I.E.’s comment. Its meaning is, to go with us from his place.

MORE. The word rabbim (more) is to be taken literally,43It is to be rendered as more. or it is to be rendered as great.44In this case, our term is to be rendered as great princes (sarim rabbim). Compare, to all the officers (rav) of his house (Esth. 1:8)45I.E. renders this as to all the great of his house. and The city46The reference is to Jerusalem. of the great king (rav) (Ps. 48:3), that is, David, for the city was called the city where David encamped (Is. 29:1).
FOR I WILL PROMOTE THEE. With money.

AND WHATSOEVER THOU SAYEST UNTO ME I WILL DO. If this is necessary for you to curse them. Balaam’s statement, If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, is proof that the meaning of For I will promote is, and I will promote you with money.47For it indicates that Balaam was hinting that he wanted to be well compensated.

HIS HOUSE FULL. Melo beto means his house full.48And not the fullness of his house. Melo khol ha-aretz kevodo (the whole earth is full of His glory) (Is. 6:3) is similar. Many err who thought that the meaning of the latter is that the contents of the earth is God’s glory,49They interpreted the verse (Is. 6:3) to mean that God’s glory consists of the contents of the earth (melo khol ha-aretz). However, this interpretation is incorrect, for God’s glory consists of much more than the contents of the earth. as in the earth is the Lord’s, and the fulness thereof (Ps. 24:1).

SMALL OR GREAT. The words ketannah (small) and gedolah (great) are adjectives. However, the nouns50Which they modify. are missing. But the rich man answers impudent51Translated literally. (Prov. 18:23)52But the rich man answers impudent is short for, but the rich answers impudent words. Thus here too the noun which the adjective modifies is missing. and, and his food fat53Translated literally. (Hab. 1:16)54And his food fat is short for, And his food a fat lamb. See I.E. on Hab. 1:16. are similar.

HERE.55Hebrew, ba-zeh, literally means in this. Hence I.E.’s comment. In this place. The Gaon, of blessed memory,56Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. says: Should someone argue and say, “How could God tell Balaam rise up, go with them (v. 20) after telling him Thou shalt not go with them (12)?”57According to the medieval Jewish philosophers, God does not change His mind. Then we can answer him that God did not want Balaam to go with these messengers but to wait until Balak sent messengers more honorable than they. However, I believe that there is no need for the Gaon’s interpretation. Its meaning is similar to God telling Israel, Send thou men (Num. 13:2) and go up, take possession (Deut. 1:21). Israel did not believe.58That they could conquer the Canaanites without first spying out the land. On the contrary, they said, Let us send men before us (Deut. 1:22). Moses then asked God.59Whether to send spies or not. God told him, Send thou men (Num. 13:2).60God told Balaam not to go to Balak to curse Israel. When Balaam told God that he wanted to go, God told him, go but do not curse Israel. In other words, the prohibition was on the cursing, not on the going. Now after God told Balaam, thou shalt not curse the people (v. 12), what need did Balaam have to say, that I may know what the Lord will speak unto me more (v. 19)? Balaam had an evil thought in his heart. God told him go with the men, but take care that you do not say anything save that which I will tell you. And God’s anger was kindled because he went (v. 22) is proof that my explanation is correct.61Otherwise, God would not have been angry at him for going, after he had received permission to go.
AND SADDLED. By command.62He did not personally saddle his donkey.

FOR AN ADVERSARY AGAINST HIM. I have already explained in the Book of Job that the adversary was an angel.63See I.E. on Job 1:6. The words of the Gaon that the adversary was a human being do not help or hinder.64They contribute nothing.
OUT OF THE WAY. Which was trodden.65The ass left the trodden path. The ass went into a field wherein there was no path.
TO TURN HER INTO THE WAY. The phrase le-hatotah ha-derekh (to turn her the way)66Translated literally. is abridged. It means to turn her into the way.

IN A HOLLOW WAY BETWEEN THE VINEYARDS. The word mishol (hollow way) is to be interpreted according to its context, for it is not found again in Scripture.67Hence we do not know its exact meaning. It should be explained as the Aramaic translation renders it.68Onkelos renders be-mishol as be-shevil (in a path).
AND SHE THRUST HERSELF UNTO THE WALL. Va-tillachetz is to be rendered, and she thrust herself.69The literal meaning of va-tillachetz is, and she was thrust. Hence I.E.’s comment.
UNTO THE WALL. The reference is to the fence.70Mentioned in the previous verse.
AND HE SMOTE HER AGAIN. For he had already hit her when she turned into the field.71Verse 23.

AND THE LORD OPENED THE MOUTH OF THE ASS. The rabbis, of blessed memory, said that ten things were created on Sabbath eve at twilight.72Among them the mouth of Balaam’s ass. See Abot 5:6. I believe that this means that God specifically decreed the creation of these miraculous phenomena,73Mentioned in Abot 5:6. for they are beyond the laws of nature.74In other words, these miraculous phenomena, one of which was the mouth of Balaam’s ass, were not actually created on Sabbath eve at twilight. God decreed that they come into being at their proper time. Maimonides makes a similar point in his commentary on Abot 5:6. The Gaon75Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. says that the ass did not speak. Rabbi Samuel the son of Hofni attacked the Gaon.76For saying this. However, Rabbi Samuel the Spanish poet tried to save the one who was attacked.77Rabbi Samuel the Spanish tried to defend Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. Note, the rationalists had a need for a non-literal interpretation of our text, for they said that God would not create signs in the world to change the laws which he created.78The rationalists argue that God would not change the laws of nature. He would do so only to justify his prophet.79The rationalists argue that God would only change the laws of nature to prove that what a prophet said was true. This was not the case with Balaam’s ass. However, they did not speak the truth, for, look, a miracle was done for Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, who were not prophets.80They were saved from a fiery furnace. See Dan. 2. Some of them81The rationalists. say that Balaam was a prophet.82Hence God suspended the laws of nature for him. However, the truth is that his prophecy83God’s appearance to Balaam. was because of Israel’s glory, for Balaam was a diviner. Indeed, this is how Scripture refers to him.84Balaam…the soothsayer (Josh. 13:22). Some say that Balaam knew the mind of the heavenly beings and was able to channel them by images that he made.85Balaam made images which had the power to manipulate the heavenly powers. This is the meaning of and he whom thou cursest is cursed (v. 6). However, it appears to me that Balaam was an astrologer. When Balaam saw in the star of a given person that an evil time had befallen him, he would curse him. When evil befell the one whom he cursed, then those who witnessed and heard the imprecation thought that the evil came because of Balaam’s curse. The fact that Balaam spoke with guile to the lords of Balak is proof of this.86First he told them that he couldn’t curse Israel. Then he hinted that he could. The meaning of I can not go beyond the word of the Lord my God (v. 18) is, it is not in the hand of any created being to change a deed or a decree of God. The secret is, the part87A human being. A human being is part of creation. can not change a part.88Any of the laws of nature. It is only the decree of the All89God. which can change the decree of the part.90Of nature. I cannot reveal this secret for it is very deep. The correct interpretation is, the ass spoke. If you understand the secret of the angels of Abraham91The angels that appeared to Abraham at Elon Moreh took the form of people. See Gen. 18:1,2. and of Jacob,92The angel that appeared to Jacob at Jabok had the form of a human. See Gen. 32:2; Gen. 32:25-31 then you will understand the truth.93The angel that appeared to Balaam took the form of a man.
[WITH HIS STAFF.] Scripture states this because Balaam first hit her with a small piece of wood or with a strap.
TIMES. I have already explained the meaning of the term regalim (times).94It means times. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 23:14. The word regel means a foot. Hence I.E.’s comment.
HAST MOCKED. I have already explained the term hitalalt (hast mocked).95I.E. explains the term to refer to manipulating events to inflict harm. See I.E. on Ex. 10:2 (Vol. 2, p. 185).
ALL THY LIFE LONG. This means from the day that you started to ride.

WAS I EVER WONT. The meaning of ha-hasken hiskanti is, was I ever wont. Its import is, was this my manner. The word hasken (acquaint)96Or habituate. in Acquaint (hasken) now thyself with him (Job 22:21) is similar.

THEN THE LORD OPENED. As in the case of Elisha’s young man (II Kings 6:17).97Who did not see the angels until God “opened his eyes.” God added to the light of his98Balaam’s. eyes99So that he could now see what he wasn’t able to see before. or first struck him blind.100And then opened his eyes.

AND BOWED HIS HEAD.101Hebrew, appav, literally, his nostrils. According to I.E. our phrase should be rendered, and he bowed with his nostrils. I have already explained its meaning.102The nostrils protrude from the face and touch the ground when one bows. See I.E. on Gen. 19 and the notes thereto (Vol. 1, p. 202).

BECAUSE THY WAY IS CONTRARY UNTO ME. The meaning of yarat (contrary) is perverse.103I.E. renders our clause, because the way [you have chosen] is perverse in my sight. The word yirteni (twists me) in And twists me by the hands of the wicked104Translated according to I.E. (Job 16:11), which comes from the root resh, tet, heh, is similar.105Thus yarat comes from the root resh, tet, heh. If yirteni comes from the root yod, resh, tet, then it should be vocalized like ye’atani106In meaning. (He hath covered me) (Is. 61:10).107Yeratani. Yarat and yirteni have similar meanings even though they come from two different roots.108The root of yarat is yod, resh, tet and yirteni comes from resh, tet, heh. We find the same to be the case with the word ye’atani (Ibid.), which is vocalized like the word ye’atzani (given me counsel) (Ps. 16:7).109Ye’atani comes from the root yod, ayin, tet. Ye’atani is similar in meaning to oteh (coverest)110From the root ayin, tet, heh. in (Who coverest Thyself with light) (Ps. 104:2).111Both of these words come from different roots but have a similar meaning.

AND THE ASS SAW ME. Va-tirani is spelled with a pattach112I.E. reads a long kamatz. However, this appears to be an error. See Filwarg. in place of a tzere. It should have been vocalized va-tireni.113See I.E. on Ex. 14:11 (Vol. 2, p. 277) and the notes thereto. There are many such cases.114See Ex. 33:20, which employs yirani in place of yireni.

UNLESS. The word ulai (unless) has many meanings. Here it means unless. The word even115Hebrew, gam, literally, also. is evidence that the ass died after she spoke.116I would have slain also you implies that he killed the ass.

AND SAVED HER ALIVE. Scripture is being brief. Its117The meaning of surely now I had even slain thee, and saved her alive. meaning is, as I killed her I would have killed you, or I would have killed you and left her alive.118And saved her alive is short for, I would have killed you and left her alive. The above is explained by the following.119And saved her alive implies that the ass died. The question arises, “Why?” When a person sees an angel, he dies. And my life is preserved (Gen. 32:1),120Stated by Jacob with reference to seeing an angel. and the words of Manoah121Manoah saw an angel and was afraid that he would die. See Jud. 13:22. are proof. How much more so the case of a beast that has nothing in common with the spirit of an angel as a human being does.
GO WITH THE MEN. With these men.
BUT ONLY. The word efes means only. The word efes (howbeit) in Howbeit there shall be no needy among you (Deut. 15: 4) and in Howbeit (efes) the people…are fierce (Num. 13:28) is similar.

WHEREFORE CAMEST THOU NOT UNTO ME. The word halakhta122Which literally means you went. is to be rendered camest because it is followed by elai (unto me). The same applies, as I have already explained,123See I.E. on Gen. 19:2 (Vol. 1, p. 202). to the word va-ysar (departed) (I Sam. 15:6).
KIRIATH-HUZOTH. It is the name of a province.124Or city.
BAMOTH-BAAL. This is to be identified with Bamotharnon (the high places of Arnon) (Num. 21:28).
AND HE SAW FROM THENCE THE UTMOST PART OF THE PEOPLE. For they camped on all four compass points.125They were spread out on all sides. Hence he saw only part of the people.

SEVEN ALTARS. There are deep secrets which only a few can fathom. The number seven occurs with regard to days,1The seventh day is holy. months,2Rosh Ha-Shanah falls on the first day of the seventh month. years;3The seventh year is a sabbatical year. The year of jubilee similarly follows seven sabbatical years. the seven lambs offered for a burnt offering;4Offered on the new moon and the festivals, with the exception of Sukkot. See Num. 28 and 29. On Sukkot, 14 lambs (2 times 7) were offered daily as a burnt offering. the seven sprinklings.5On Yom Kippur and on the leper. See Lev. 16:14; 14:7. All of these are among these secrets. God also told Job, take unto you seven bullocks and seven rams (Job 42:8). When the complete6Seven is a complete number. is added to the complete,7To seven. When seven bullocks are added to seven lambs and placed on seven altars. Or when seven animals are sacrificed to God the complete, the celebrant is prophetically inspired. then a spirit of understanding is newly created.8In the celebrant; i.e., he is prophetically inspired. The intelligent will understand what I speak of.

ON EVERY ALTAR A BULLOCK AND A RAM.9Literally, a bullock and a ram on the altar. On each and every altar.10Balaam built seven altars. It is unlikely that he built seven altars and used only one. Hence I.E.’s comment. Scripture is being brief. It is short for, on one of the many altars.11Balaam used all seven altars. However, Scripture tells us what he offered on one of the altars.

WILL COME. Yikkareh (will come) is derived from li-kerati (to meet me).12Thus yikkareh means will meet me. AND WHATSOEVER13Hebrew, devar mah. HE SHOWETH ME. The word devar is connected to mah.14Even though the word mah is connected by hyphen to yareni (He showeth me), for the word devar is in the construct. If the word were in the absolute it would be vocalized davar. Thus our text should be read, u-devar-mah yareni (And whatsoever He showeth me), rather than u-devar mah-yareni. (And a thing of, what will He show me).
The term devar means “thing of.” Mah literally means what.

AND HE WENT TO A BARE HEIGHT. The manner in which the Aramaic translator renders shefi (bare) is known. He translates shefi as alone.15Onkelos renders our clause, and he went alone. Now shefi is alone; it is also without a brother.16That is, it is not found again in Scripture. Other say that the word shefi means broken in heart (Ps. 109:16).17These commentaries render our clause: And he went with a broken heart. They say that the word shefi is related to shuppu (corrode) in and his bones corrode (Job 33:21). However, I believe that the word shefi is related to shefayim (high hills) in upon the high hills is heard (Jer. 3:20). The word is found spelled both with a yod18In Job 33:21. and with an alef.19Is. 49:9. See I.E. on Is. 49:9. It should be pointed out that our texts of Is. 49:9 do not spell the word with an alef. We find the same thing with the word peta’im (simple) (Prov. 1:4).20It is sometimes spelled with an alef, and other times with a yod. The meaning of va-elekh shefi (and he went to a bare height) is, he went to a high hill. The word el (to) has been omitted from the phrase.21Our text should be read as if written va-elekh el shefi. Our texts reads va-elekh shefi, which literally means, and he went to high place. Hence I.E.’s comment. We find the same in va-yavo yerushalayim (and he came to Jerusalem)22This should be read as if written va-yavo el yerushalayim (and he came to Jerusalem), for the literal meaning of va-yavo yerushalayim is, and he came Jerusalem. (I Kings 3:15) and in nase’u ha-am hazerot (the people journeyed unto Hazeroth)23This should be read as if written nase’u ha-am el hazerot (the people journeyed unto Hazeroth), for nase’u ha-am hazerot means the people journeyed Hazeroth. (Num. 11:35). There are many such instances.24Where the preposition el has to be added to the text. Observe, Balaam was divining25I.E. does not describe the divination which Balaam employed. He may have cast lots, read the entrails of sacrificed animals, interpreted clouds, or the like. when he went,26To the mountain. for Scripture clearly states, he went not, as at other times27Which implies that until then he divined. to meet with enchantments28Divining. (Num. 24:1). See, I have given you a hint regarding a sealed secret.29That Balaam practiced enchantment using the number seven.
AND I HAVE OFFERED UP A BULLOCK AND A RAM ON EVERY ALTAR. By command.30He commanded Balak to build these altars and place the offerings on them. See verse 1.
AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE, AND SAID. The parable referred to is, For from the top of rocks I see him (v. 9).31Verses 7 and 8 are not parables.
FROM THE MOUNTAINS OF THE EAST. The word kedem means east.32The word kedem can also mean old.

COME, CURSE ME JACOB. “And he said” has been omitted from our clause.33Our verse should be read as if written, And he said: Come curse me Jacob, and come… We find many such instances in the Song of Songs. This is an abridged style.

EXECRATE ISRAEL. Scripture repeats itself 34And come execrate Israel repeats Come curse me Jacob. as is its custom. Its manner is to employ different words to express the same thought. It repeats itself for emphasis. The word zo’amah (execrate)35Zo’amah is vocalized with a cholam. should have been vocalized like the word zokhrah (remember)36Zokrah is vocalized with a short kamatz. in Remember unto me, O my God (Neh. 5:19). However, since the ayin37Of zo’amah. was vocalized with a pattach38Rather than with a sheva. because it is a guttural, a cholam rather than a short kamatz was placed between it and the zayin.

HOW SHALL I CURSE, WHOM GOD HATH NOT CURSED. The word kabboh means to curse. Its heh is in place of a vav.39The word is spelled kabboh rather than kabbo. The latter is the usual form. Hence I.E.’s comment. It is like the heh in oholoh40The word is written oholoh rather than the more usual oholo. (his tent) (Gen. 12:8) and the heh in fera’oh41Rather than fe’aro. (let them loose) in for Aaron had let them loose (Ex. 32:25). Kabboh comes from a double root.42Its root is kaf, bet, bet. Its full form43In the perfect. is kavevo (they curse him). Compare, savevo44From the root samekh, bet, bet. Both double root letters are present in savevu. (they surrounded him) although it is irregular.45The word savevo is not found in Scripture (Krinsky). The form used is sevavuhu (I Kings 5:17). For other interpretations see Filwarg and Meijler.

AND HOW SHALL I EXECRATE, WHOM GOD HATH NOT EXECRATED. The words ezam (shall I execrate) and za’am (execrate) come from the root, zayin, ayin, mem (anger). Scripture repeats itself.46The second half of our verse repeats the first half.

FOR FROM THE TOP OF THE ROCKS I SEE HIM. Balaam said this because he was high up on the hill. He went not, as at other times, to meet with enchantments. But he set his face toward the wilderness (Num. 24:1)47I.E. assumes that the wilderness is a flat area. and not toward the high place48Which he previously faced. is proof that my interpretation of shefi49See I.E. on verse 3. is correct.50For Scripture contrasts midbar (wilderness), which is a flat area, with sefi. Thus sefi must refer to an elevated area. It is also likely that from the top of the rocks is a parable symbolizing the decrees that come down from heaven. For Balaam in his wisdom51Which came to him from on high. saw that this nation would stand alone and not intermingle with other nations that would overpower her and try to force her to give up God’s Torah, as the nations did.
AND SHALL NOT BE RECKONED AMONG THE NATIONS. I will explain this in my comments on When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance (Deut. 32:8).

WHO HATH COUNTED. It is a wonder that Israel is not counted with the nations, when they are a nation as numerous as the sand. It is likely for a small nation not to be counted.52Because of its insignificance, but not a large one whose number is like the sand.
THE DUST OF JACOB. Its meaning is: Jacob is as numerous as the dust of the earth.

OR NUMBERED THE STOCK OF ISRAEL? One standard.53I.E. interprets rova (stock) as a quarter. The camp of Israel was divided into four standards (Num 2:1-31). Thus a quarter of Israel was one standard. It means the same as thou shalt see but the utmost part of them, and shalt not see them all (v. 13).54The idea of our verse is, who can count even part of Israel.

[LET ME DIE THE DEATH OF THE RIGHTEOUS, AND LET MINE END BE LIKE HIS!] The Aramaic translator beautifully explained the meaning of yesharim (the righteous).55Onkelos renders yesharim as the honest.I believe that Balaam wanted to die. He wanted his end to be like the end of Israel, who are God’s portion and are not ruled by the stars, for he was a magician.56According to this interpretation Balaam made two requests: to die the death of the righteous and to be granted a share in the world to come. Others say that mine end repeats let me die. Balaam wanted to die like the righteous of Israel, for he knew that he would die by the sword.57According to this interpretation Balaam had one request, to die the death of Israel. The Bible merely repeats itself. The Gaon58Rabbi Saadiah Gaon. says that Who hath counted refers to God. Our verse means: You who are able to count the dust of Jacob, give me the death of the righteous. However, if this is so, then what meaning is there to Or numbered the stock of Israel?59For Balaam would not say to God, You who are able to count a standard of Israel after saying, You who are able to count the dust of Israel. Many explain that rova (the stock of) is similar in meaning to rivi, which means my lying down. Compare, Thou measurest my going about and my lying down (rivi) (Ps. 139:3). They explain that the dust of Jacob refers to the time that Jacob journeys.60They interpret our verse as follows: Who can count Israel when Israel camps; Who can count Israel when Israel journeys.

[THOU HAST BLESSED THEM ALTOGETHER.] It is normal usage to place the infinitive first in the perfect and then the imperfect.61When Scripture wants to emphasize a point, it repeats the verb. It does so by placing the infinitive form first and then the appropriate verb next. See Gen. 31:30; Ex. 19:5; and Jud. 15:2. The reverse is true in the imperative.62In the imperative the infinitive comes first and the imperative second. See Is. 6:9. However, there are irregular phrases such as u-verakhta barekh63Here the infinitive (barekh) comes last. (thou hast blessed them altogether) (Num. 24:10); and yava vo64Here too the infinitive (vo) comes last. (and he shall come on) in and he shall come on, and overflow, as he passeth through (Dan. 11:1).
BUT THE UTMOST. The meaning of efes katzehu is, but the utmost.

AND CURSE ME THEM. Ve-kovno (and curse them) is irregular.65The word should have read ve-kavnu, for that is the rule when a nun vav is used to indicate the pronoun. According to the rules of grammar the imperative is the same as the imperfect.66It is vocalized similarly. The only difference between them is the prefix.67A prefix is placed before the verb in the imperfect. Compare, yirdefehu (he shall pursue him); yirdefenu (he shall pursue him); yirdefuhu (they shall pursue him); and yirdefo (shall pursue him68The pronoun him is represented by a cholam only when a heh vav or a nun vav is not used to indicate the pronoun.) in The enemy shall pursue him (Hos. 8:3).69These are examples of verbs in the imperfect combined with the pronoun. However, kovno comes with a nun vocalized with a cholam joined to the root. According to Rabbi Judah, the first grammarian, the word kovno comes from the root kof, bet, nun.70Thus the nun is not a sign of the pronoun. The word kovno is similar to yirdefo; i.e., the pronoun is represented by a cholam. If this is the case, then kovno cannot be an imperative, for we do not find such a vocalization in the kal.71We do not find the imperative combined with the pronoun him signified by a vav (Filwarg). Perhaps kovno is an infinitive vocalized like the word shomro (keep) in and because He would keep the oath (Deut. 7:8).
AND HE TOOK UP HIS PARABLE. The reference is to like the lofty horns of the wild-ox (v. 22) and a people that riseth up as a lioness (v. 24).

GIVE EAR UNTO ME. The word adai (unto me) is related to the word ad (unto). The word adai (unto Me) in Yet have ye not returned unto Me (Amos 4:6) is similar. Scripture repeats itself.72The second part of the last clause repeats its first part. The vav in beno tzippor (son of Zippor) is superfluous.73Here beno means son of, not his son. It is similar to the vav of le-mayeno (a fountain) in into a fountain of waters (Ps. 114:8).74Le-mayeno in this verse means a fountain of, not a fountain.

[GOD IS NOT A MAN.] Balaam said this in response to Balak’s request, and curse me them from thence (v. 13). However, Balaam had already told him, God hath not cursed (v. 8).75He therefore told him now that God is not a man and consequently does not alter His words.
WHEN HE HATH SAID, WILL HE NOT DO IT? His word.76It refers to His word.
OR WHEN HE HATH SPOKEN. A word.
