READY. The word chushim (ready) is vocalized like the word mulim (circumcised) in were circumcised (Josh. 5:5). It means quickly. It is related to the word chushah (hasten) in Make speed, hasten, stay not (I Sam. 20:38).

AND FORWARD. The word ve-hale’ah (and forward) is used with regard to both place25See Gen. 35:21: And Israel journeyed, and spread his tent beyond (me-hale’ah) Migdal-eder. and time.26See Lev. 22:27. But from the eighth day and thenceforth (ve-hale’ah). The meaning of ve-hale’ah is, and above.27That is, forward.
UNTIL HE HATH DRIVEN OUT. God.28Horisho (He hath driven out) refers to God.

BEFORE THE LORD. For the ark was there.29Among the people. Before the Lord is to be taken as I have explained,30See I.E. on Ex. 16:34 (Vol. 2, p. 332). Before the Lord means before the divine glory which is upon the cherubim. for the phrase31Li-fene Adonai. is always used in a positive sense.32The word li-fene Adonai (before the Lord) literally means before the Lord’s face. This can be taken in a negative sense, that is, to anger God. See I.E. on the word li-fene in Gen. 11:28 (Vol. 1, p. 146).

FOR YOUR SHEEP. The alef in tzonakhem (your sheep) is superfluous.33The usual form of the word is tzonkhem. It is like the alef in he’eznichu (become foul) in and the rivers shall become foul (Is. 19:6).34Which is superfluous. The usual form is hiznichu.

EVERY MAN THAT IS ARMED FOR WAR. Kol chalutz tzava (every man that is armed for war) is similar to ha-aron ha-berit35Ha-aron has a heh, the definite article, prefixed to it. Such a word cannot be in the construct. Hence our phrase reads, the ark, the covenant. This should be read as if written, the ark, ark of the covenant. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54, and the notes thereto). (the ark of the covenant) (Josh. 3:14). Its meaning is, every man armed, armed for war.36In I.E.’s edition of the Pentateuch the word chalutz was apparently vocalized with a kamatz. This being the case, the verse read, armed, war. Hence I.E. suggests that our verse be read as if written, armed, armed for war (Motot). It should be noted that in our versions of Scripture the word chalutz is vocalized with a chataf pattach and is in the construct with tzava. It thus reads, armed for war.

THEN YE SHALL GIVE THEM. The meaning of u-netattem la-hem is, you shall give them.37In other words, the vav prefixed to netattem does not mean and. It is placed there for emphasis and is not to be translated. The vav is like the Arabic fa,38See I.E. On Gen. 1:2, (Vol. 1, p. 30). for such is the rule of the language.39To employ a non-translatable yod.

THEY SHALL HAVE POSSESSIONS AMONG YOU. He gave them respect,40He spoke to them with respect. for the meaning of our verse is, if they41The tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half tribe of Manasseh. will not go armed before you, then you shall force them to go with you and they shall have possessions among you.42Our verse says this in a diplomatic way. Or, if they change their minds, then they shall have possessions among you. The word ve-nochazu (they shall have possessions) follows the rules of a root that has a yod as its first letter,43Ve-nochazu is vocalized as if it came from the root yod, chet zayin, when in reality its root is alef, chet, zayin. for the letters alef, heh, vav, and yod interchange.
AND THE CHILDREN OF GAD…ANSWERED. A second time for emphasis.

WE WILL PASS. The form nachnu (we) is the original form of the word. The alef in anachnu (we)44The more usual employed term for we. is added. The half tribe of Manasseh is not mentioned until now because it was but half a tribe.
AND NEBO. It is likely that the reference is to Mount Nebo, where, as I shall explain,45See I.E. on Deut. 34:6. Moses was buried.

THEIR NAMES BEING CHANGED. These cities had their names changed.46In other words, musabbot shem (their names being changed) is not the name of a city. The same applies to Sibmah.47Its name was also changed.

AND DISPOSSESSED. Some say that Machir was alive.48That Machir the son of Manasseh was still alive, and that it is he to whom va-yoresh (and [he] dispossessed) applies. These commentaries interpret thus because verse 40 states, And Moses gave Gilead unto Machir. The latter is taken literally. However, I believe that and dispossessed49Literally, and he dispossessed. refers to the warrior that was in the family.50One of Machir’s descendants was a great warrior. He dispossessed the Amorites.

[UNTO MACHIR THE SON OF MANASSEH.] The meaning of unto Machir the son of Manasseh is, unto the sons of Machir the son of Manasseh.51For Machir the son of Manasseh was no longer alive. Compare, And Judah said unto Simeon his brother (Jud. 1:3).52The meaning of which is, and the descendants of Judah said to the descendants of Simeon his brother, for the tribal patriarchs Reuben and Judah were no longer alive.

AND JAIR THE SON OF MANASSEH. Jair was from the family of Judah.53From the tribe of Judah. This raises the question: Why does Scripture identify him as a son of Manasseh? This is explicitly stated.54In Scripture. For Hezron55The son of Judah. took the daughter of Machir the son of Manasseh, and she bore him Segub. Segub begot Jair,56See I Chron. 2:1-22. who had cities among the cities of Gilead.57Ibid. Jair is called after his mother’s family. There were also kohanim who were called after the name of the children of Barzillai the Gileadite.58The children of Barzillai were not kohanim. The latter is clearly stated in Scripture.59See Ezra 2:61. This is no reason to ask: How did Jair60Who was from the tribe of Judah. inherit among another tribe,61Manasseh. Each tribe was allocated a portion by lot. Only members of the tribe received a portion in the land belonging to the tribe. The question thus arises, by what right did Jair receive a part of the land within the area allocated to Manasseh. for it was the land of Canaan that was divided,62By lot. not the land of the Amorites that was on the eastern side of the Jordan,63The land on the eastern bank of the Jordan was not allocated by lot to the tribe of Manasseh. Hence it was possible for Jair to obtain a part of the eastern bank of the Jordan by conquest. for64What follows is merely noted for informational purposes. It does no affect the interpretation. there were Amorites in the land of Canaan65As there were in Transjordan. and they were the mightiest of the seven nations.
THE VILLAGES THEREOF. Chavvotehem (villages thereof) is to be interpreted in context.66The word is not found elsewhere in Scripture. It means walled cities.

THESE ARE THE STAGES. Moses recorded all the journeys of the Israelites when the children of Israel camped in the plains of Moab1Verse 48. and stayed there for a number of months, until the afore-mentioned cities2The cities mentioned in Num. 32:33-42. were built. They did not move from there until Aaron died.3This appears to be an error, for Aaron died at Mount Hor before Israel came to the plains of Moab. See Num. 20:22-29. The proper reading should be, until Moses died.
THEIR GOINGS FORTH. How they went from place to place. Therefore their goings forth follows.
BY THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD. This is connected to stage by stage.4Our text should be read: Stage by stage by the commandment of the Lord.
ON THE MORROW AFTER THE PASSOVER. I have explained this,5See I.E. on Lev. 23:11. and with a high hand (Ex. 14:8)6See I.E. on Lev. 23:11. as well.

UPON THEIR GODS ALSO THE LORD EXECUTED JUDGMENTS. As in the incident with Dagan’s head.7I Sam. 5:4. Dagan fell headless, armless, and footless before the ark of God. For God said so to Moses.8In other words, God executed judgment as he had told Moses he would (Ex. 12:12). I. E. notes this because Scripture does not previously tells us that God actually executed judgment on the Egyptian gods.

AND TURNED BACK. This alludes to the cloud9Which accompanied Israel. Va-yisu (and they journeyed) is in the plural. Va-yashav (and turned back) is in the singular. Thus our verse may be rendered: and they journeyed and it turned back. Hence I.E.’s interpretation. or to Israel.10According to this interpretation Scripture refers to Israel in the singular.

FROM PENE-HAHIROTH. Pene-hahirot and Pi-hahiroth11See Ex. 14:2. refers to the same place. The mouth is in the face.12Pi means mouth of; pene face of. Hence the names Pi-hahiroth and Pene-hahiroth for the same place.
THREE DAYS’ JOURNEY. I have already explained this.13See I.E. on Num. 10:31.
KIBROTH-HATTAAVAH. The latter is in Kadesh-barnea,14See I.E. on Num. 20:14. as I explained.
AND THEY JOURNEYED FROM KADESH. Kadesh is the name of a city.15See I.E. on Num. 20:14.
[AND THE CANAANITE…HEARD.] Scripture tells us this here16After mentioning Mount Hor. because the Canaanite fought with Israel at Hor ha-Hor.17Following the death of Aaron. See Num. 21:1-3.
ZALMONAH, AND…PUNON. I have explained this.18See I.E. on Num. 21:4.
ALMON-DIBLATHAIM. This is a general term for many journeys, as I explained in the Torah portion, This is the statute of the law (Num. 19:2).19See I.E. on Num. 21:18.

FROM BETH-JESHIMOTH. This is the valley which looks down upon the wasteland.20See I.E. on Num. 21:20. God then commanded Moses to warn Israel21To drive out the inhabitants of Canaan (v. 55). because they were soon to pass over.22Into Canaan.
THEIR FIGURED STONES. Maskiyyotam (their figured stones) is similar to ve-even maskit (any figured stone) (Lev. 26:1).
THEIR HIGH PLACES. Bamotam means their high places. Compare, bamate aretz (the high places of the earth) (Is. 58:14).

AND YE SHALL INHERIT THE LAND. Ve-hitnachaltem (and ye shall inherit) is similar to ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) (Num. 34 :10).23Both verbs are in the hitpa’el and are transitive. Most verbs in the hitpa’el are intransitive. Hence I.E.’s comment. Ha-aretz (the land) is the object.24In other words, ve-hitnachaltem is transitive.

Scripture mentions to the more ye shall give the more inheritance to connect But if ye will not drive out the inhabitants (v. 55) which comes after it.25In other words, the law commanding Israel to drive out the Canaanites follows the law telling Israel to inherit Canaan, in order to warn Israel that they will not inherit the land if they permit Canaanites to dwell therein.

AS THORNS. Sikkim refers to sharp thorns. It is related to the word mesukkato (hedge thereof)26The hedge spoken of in Is. 5:5 was made of sharp thorns. in the hedge thereof (Is. 5:5) and the word sakh (hedge) in behold, I will hedge up thy way with thorns (Hos. 2:8).

AND AS PRICKS. The word tzeninim (pricks) is to be explained according to its context. It means the same as u-leshotet be-tziddekhem (a scourge in your sides) (Josh. 23:13), which27According to its context. See Weiser. refers to a blow delivered by a whip.28So too the word tzeninim. Thus ve-litzninim be-tziddekhem (and as pricks in your sides) means, and lashes in their sides. On the other hand, the word tzeninim (pricks) might refer to sharp thorns, as in Thorns (tzinnim) and snares in the way of the froward (Prov. 22:5).29In this case, ve-litzninim be-tziddekhem (and for pricks in your sides) means, and for thorns in their sides. Observe, Scripture further explains30In chapter 34. the borders of their inheritance from which they are obligated to expel the inhabitants of the land.

INTO THE LAND OF CANAAN. Ha-aretz kena’an (the land of Canaan) is similar to ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet) (II Chron. 15:8), the meaning of which is, the prophecy, prophecy of Oded the prophet. The meaning of our clause is, the land, land of Canaan.1Ha-aretz has the definite article prefixed to it. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar, a word with the definite article cannot be in the construct. The literal meaning of ha-aretz kena’an (the land of Canaan) thus is, the land Canaan. Hence I.E.’s comment that our verse be read as if written, ha-aretz, eretz kena’an. Ve-hanevu’ah oded ha-navi (even the prophecy of Oded the prophet) (II Chron. 15:8) is, for similar reasons, to be read, ve-hanevu’ah nevu’at oded ha-navi. See I.E. on Gen. 2:9 (Vol. 1, p. 54).

BY THE SIDE OF EDOM. The word yede2Literally, hands of. Hence I.E.’s comment. (side of) means place of. Compare, by the side of (yad)3Literally, hand of. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26 (Vol. 1, pp. 45-46). the Jordan (Num. 13:29).
UNTO THE BROOK OF EGYPT. Nachlah mitzrayim means unto the brook of Egypt.4For the heh suffixed to nachlah is in place of the preposition el (unto). It does not refer to the Nile.

THE GREAT SEA. The Spanish sea.5I.E.’s term for the Mediterranean Sea. The meaning of our verse is: And the Great Sea shall be your western border.6Our verse reads, u-gavel yam. This should be rendered, and for the western border not, and the sea. The word yam can mean either the sea or the west. Hence I.E.’s comment. The Great Sea itself shall serve as the border.7Our verse literally reads, and the border on the west, ye shall have the Great Sea, and a border. I.E. renders this, you shall have the Great Sea itself serve as your border on the west

AND YE SHALL MARK OUT. The alef in ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) is in place of a vav.8Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, in place of a tav. The root of ve-hitavvitem appears to be alef, vav, heh. This root means to desire. And you shall desire appears out of place here. Hence I.E.’s suggestion that ve-hitavvitem comes from the root tav, vav, heh, which means to mark out. And you shall mark out fits in well within the context of our verse. Compare, ve-hitvita9Which comes from the root tav, vav, heh. tav (and set a mark) (Ezek. 9:4). This is so, even though the forms differ.10Ve-hitavvitem is in the hitpa’el while ve-hitvita is a hif’il.

AND YE SHALL MARK OUT. Ve-hitavvitem (and ye shall mark out) is similar to the word ta’avat (utmost bound) in Unto the utmost bound of the everlasting hills (Gen. 49:26).11I.E. makes the same point in Genesis. See Vol. 1, p. 447.

AND SHALL STRIKE. The word machah (strike) is to be interpreted as the ancients did. It means it shall break.12When the boundary line reaches the lake of Kinneret, it will create a broken (not a straight) border (Weiser). It is related to the word yimcha’u (clap) in Let the floods clap their hands (Ps. 98:8).

THE TWO TRIBES. Scripture mentions this a second time13The first half of our verse repeats the previous verse. in order to explain the place of their inheritance.14The second part of our verse tells us where the two and a half tribes received their inheritance.

SHALL TAKE POSSESSION. Yinchalu (shall take possession) is a causative.15Even though it is a kal. According to I. E. the word yinchalu here should be rendered, shall cause you to take possession, rather than shall take possession. The same applies to the word u-nechaltanu (and take us for Thine inheritance) (Ex. 34:9)16According to I.E., u-nechaltanu (and take us for Thine inheritance) should be rendered, you will cause us to inherit. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 34:9. in the opinion of the grammarians.

ELEAZAR. He is mentioned first17Before Joshua. because Joshua went out by his command. Furthermore, Eleazar was also the son of Aaron. Scripture does not mention the princes of the tribes of Reuben or Gad,18In listing the princes of the tribes in verses 17-28. for they19Their tribes. had already taken their share. The commentaries say that Scripture starts20In listing the tribes. with Judah,21Even though Simeon was older. for that is the way the lot came out at first.22When the land was actually divided. See Joshua 15:1. However, there is a great argument against them.23If Scripture followed the order in which the tribes actually received their inheritance, the children of Joseph should have followed Judah, for they took their inheritance after Judah. See Joshua 16. Nevertheless, the comments appear correct to us.24For no one can offer a better reason than these commentaries for listing Judah first (Weiser).

PEDAHEL. If the heh in Pedahel is silent then we have two words each with its own meaning,25The heh is silent only when it comes at the end of a word. It is not silent when it comes in the middle of a word. Since the heh in the name Pedahel is silent we must interpret it as two words, padah el (God redeemed). I.E.’s point is that while many of the Hebrew names containing God’s name are partially abbreviated, this is not the case with Pedahel. for the heh is not an implied letter.26In the middle of a word. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 (Vol. 2, p. 85).
AND OPEN LAND. The meaning of migrash (open land) is known.1Hence there is no need to explain its meaning.

INTO THE LAND OF CANAAN. The meaning of artzah kena’an (into the land of Canaan) is known.2The heh of artzah is in place of the preposition el. Thus artzah kena’an means into the land of Canaan. This chapter, like others,3Like other chapters which I.E. had previously pointed out. is connected.4To the chapter which precedes it.

THEN YE SHALL APPOINT YOU CITIES. The word ve-hikritem (then shall ye appoint you) is related to the word kiryah (cities).5From the word kir, a wall. Kiryah is thus a walled city. Ve-hikritem lakhem arim thus means, and you shall build walled cities.

FOR THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This is not connected to the previous verse,6Our verse is not a continuation of the previous verse. It is an independent clause. for the preceding verse states that these cities will be cities of refuge. However, it does not state for whom they shall serve as cities of refuge. Scripture then explains7In our verse. that these six cities shall serve as cities of refuge for the children of Israel, and for the stranger…who lives among them.

WHEN HE MEETETH HIM. The feh of bi-figo (when he meeteth him) is vocalized with a chirik8In place of a short kamatz. Compare shomoro, kotvo, etc. like the word shivri (I break) in when I break (Lev. 26:26), for vocalization changes in the infinitive.9Not all infinitives follow the same vocalization.
AND IF HE THRUST HIM. From a high place.
OR HURLED AT HIM. An inclining wall10Pushed the wall down upon him. or a deadly object.
LYING IN WAIT. I have previously explained the meaning of bi-tzediyyah (lying in wait).11See I.E. on Ex. 21:13.
SUDDENLY. The meaning of be-feta is suddenly.12The usual word for suddenly is pitom. Hence I.E.’s comment.
SEEING HIM NOT. Re’ot is an infinitive.
AND HE WAS NOT HIS ENEMY. He had no intention of seeking his harm.

THEREIN UNTIL THE DEATH OF THE HIGH PRIEST. Some say that the meaning of until the death of is, until the investigation of.13Until the high priest investigates the death of the victim. For other interpretations see Filwarg. They compare it to And wisdom shall die with you (Job. 12:2).14They render this, and with you is wisdom searched out. However, what they say is worthless. For And wisdom shall die with you means exactly what it says,15Tamut means shall die, not shall search out. as does until the death of the high priest.16Which is to be taken literally. For the high priest atones on behalf of Israel, and this incident happened during his lifetime.17Hence the murderer shall remain in the city of exile to remind the high priest of his failing. The high priest’s piety should have prevented the murder (see Rashi). Or, the murderer shall remain in exile to remind the high priest to pray constantly that God forgive Israel for the bloodshed in its midst.

THE BORDER OF HIS CITY. Et gevul means beyond18Literally, from. the border.19The word et is usually not translated. Hence I.E. points out that here it means from. Compare, et ha-ir (out of the city) in as I am gone out of the city (Ex. 9:29).

BLOODGUILTINESS. I have already explained the meaning of dam (bloodguiltiness).20Our clause literally reads, he has no blood. Hence I.E. points out that blood means bloodshed. Thus our clause should be rendered, he is not guilty of bloodshed. See I.E. on Ex. 22:1.
SO YE SHALL NOT POLLUTE. Do evil in secret.

SHED IT. Shofkho (shed it) is a verb.21Not a noun. It is made up of the verb shofekh (shedder) and the word shelo (its) Compare go’alo (his redeemer)22Which is a verb made up of the word go’el (redeems) and shelo (him) (translated according to I.E.). in then shall his redeemer…come (Lev. 25:25).

AND THOU SHALT NOT DEFILE23Hebrew, titamme. Titamme can be rendered either as you shall defile or it shall defile. Hence the interpretations which follow. THE LAND. The pollution shall not defile the land.24This interpretation renders ve-lo titamme, it shall not defile. Or it is a command.25This interpretation renders ve-lo titamme, you shall not defile. The land shall not be polluted because I dwell among them.26I.E.’s paraphrase of the Lord dwells in the midst of the children of Israel. I do not dwell there out of respect for the land but out of respect for the children of Israel. Therefore Scripture says, I the Lord dwell in the midst of the children of Israel (v. 34).

CAME NEAR. This chapter1Like other chapters. also is connected to the one that comes before it. When Moses commanded the Israelites to give the Levites cities from the inheritance of Israel [the heads of the fathers’ houses drew near].
THE HEADS OF THE FATHERS’ HOUSES. The reference is to the princes.2Of the tribes. Hence Scripture reads, before the princes, the heads of the fathers’ houses of the children of Israel (v. 1).

AND WHEN THE JUBILEE…SHALL BE. Even if the jubilee shall be,3I.E. renders ve-im yiheyah ha-yovel (and when the jubilee shall be), and even if the jubilee shall be. we have no hope of the inheritance returning to us, for it shall be added to the inheritance of the tribe.4Into which they married.
THE TRIBE OF THE SONS OF JOSEPH SPEAKETH RIGHT. For the heads of the fathers’ houses spoke on behalf of the entire tribe.

[SO SHALL NO INHERITANCE OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL REMOVE FROM TRIBE TO TRIBE.] The meaning of tissov (remove) is, shall not turn5Shall not move around. Tissov comes from the root samekh, bet, bet, meaning to turn. from here to there,6Emending mi-po u-mi-po (from here and from here) to mi-po le-po (from here to there) (Filwarg). be it from them7The tribe of Joseph, who argued their case before Moses. or from others.8Any other tribe.
The meaning of so shall no inheritance be removed is, no inheritance shall be removed from this day and onward even though they had not as yet inherited the land.

AND EVERY DAUGHTER, THAT POSSESSETH AN INHERITANCE. After the inheritance of the land. Scripture therefore states a second time, So shall no inheritance remove [from one tribe to another tribe] (v. 9).9In other words, verse 7 speaks of the present. Verse 8 speaks of the future.
MAHLAH, TIRZAH. Scripture first mentioned them10In Num. 27:1. in the order of their birth. It now mentions them in the order in which they were first taken by men in marriage.

THEY WERE MARRIED INTO THE FAMILIES. This11The word families. is a sign that their cousins12The cousins who married the daughters of Zelophehad. were not all brothers.13If they were, then Scripture would have read, they were married into the “family” rather than they married into the “families.”

THESE ARE THE COMMANDMENTS. Relating to inheritance,14Num. 33:50-56; 34; 35:1-8. vows,15Num. 30:2-17. and every daughter that possesseth an inheritance,16Num. 36:8,9. and the laws regarding bloodshed.17Num. 35:9-34.
BY THE JORDAN AT JERICHO. On the eastern bank.
